loans.name: Women Group

texts.en:
Lucy has owned a tailoring business in Arusha for eight years. She is 34 years old, married, and has two children ages 3 and 8. She works every day from 7:00am to 9:00pm and generates a monthly profit of approximately $250.

Lucy has taken out two previous loans through BRAC Tanzania. She paid back both successfully and on time. She is hoping to use this loan to buy a sewing machine and other items to help her run her business. She will be sharing this loan with her three other group members who also own retail shops. Their shops sell beer, vegetables, and clothing, respectively.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine and other items for her business.

loans.name: Sutriyani

texts.id: Usaha jual ayam goreng yang dijalani oleh Sutriyani cukup mengalami peningkatan. Dari hasil usahanya ini, dia sudah bisa melunasi pinjaman sebelumnya. Kali ini merupakan periode pinjaman kedua bagi Sutriyani, dan dia berharap mendapat jumlah pinjaman yang lebih besar dari sebelumnya. Pada pinjaman pertama dia mendapatkan bantuan modal usaha sebesar Rp.800.000. Modal tersebut telah dipergunakan untuk mendukung usahanya dengan membeli daging ayam, bumbu dan sayur-sayuran untuk lalapan. Usahanya ini saat ini bisa menambah penghasilannya dari Rp.60.000 menjadi Rp.100.000 setiap hari. Dengan kenaikan dari segi pendapatan dia berharap nantinya bisa mengembalikan pinjaman kedua ini tepat waktu seperti pinjaman pertama. Selain untuk memenuhi kebutuhan hidup sehari-hari, keuntungan yang diperoleh juga dipakai untuk menabung bagi pendidikan dan kesehatan bagi bayinya yang berusia 14 bulan.
texts.en:
Sutriyani’s Fried Chicken business is developing. From the business, she is able to repay her previous loan. This time is her second round of loan, and she expects to receive bigger amount of it. From her first loan, she received IDR 800.000 (USD 87.9). The loan was used to buy chicken meat, seasoning, and fresh vegetables that goes with the meal she is selling. From the loan and the business, she gains from IDR 60.000 (USD 6.6) to IDR 100.000 (USD 10.98) a day. With the income raise, she hopes to repay her second loan on time like she did for the first loan. The profit from her business will be used to support her daily needs and to save for education and health care of her 14-months old baby.

Translated from Indonesian by Iman Madaze, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To add business capital

loans.name: Khadija

texts.en:
Khadija is married. She has run her own general store since 2005. Currently she earns a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Khadija is now requesting a loan to expand her stock.

loans.use: To buy more items for her general store.

loans.name: Felix Angel

texts.es:
Don Félix Ángel  Fúnez L. con edad de 45 años su estado civil es de casado, el tiene  6 hijos  las edades de sus hijos son de 25,23 y 20 años de edad respectivamente los varones, los cuales no dependen de el directamente ya que trabajan por cuenta propia las mujeres tienen edades  de 16, 6 y 3 años la niña de16 años cursa la secundaria y la niña de 6 años cursa la primaria y la de 3 años todavía no asiste a clases, su esposa es la que se dedica a la comercialización de la venta de carne de res y ganado en pie, por lo que el señor se encarga de buscar en las diferentes comunidades los animales para su debida comercialización  y para el destace de forma semanal, la señora es su apoyo principal en  la administración del negocio, además de obtener estos ingresos como comerciante el señor también se dedica a ofrecer el servicio de transporte ya que  tiene la facilidad de un camión, lo que le facilita brindar este servicio, además de la comercialización de granos básicos, obteniendo otros ingresos que le ayuden a los diferentes gastos de su casa, uno de los propósitos que el tiene es poder comprar en un corto plazo otro camión el cual vendría a ampliar su segmento de mercado, y aprovechar la oportunidad y así poder brindar a sus clientes el servicio de transporte.

Don Félix solicita su crédito numero 6 aunque el cuenta con mas de 12 años de trabajar con la fundación león 2000, la actividad  económica de don Félix es la compra venta y destace de ganado en el domicilio de telica  y cuenta con mas de 12 años de experiencia en su negocio, el negocio surge de la necesidad de tener una fuente de ingreso para mantener a su familia ya que cada día que pasaba su familia  crecía y debía mantenerla al pasar del tiempo logro comparar un camión que ayudara a trasladar y facilitara el movimiento de su actividad económica para que con la ayuda de las organizaciones pueda poder realizar su sueños
texts.en:
Félix Ángel Fúnez L. is 45 years old and he is married. He has 6 children aged 25, 23, and 20 years old respectively and they are the boys. They no longer depend on him because they are all working. The girls are aged 16, 6 and 3 years old. The 16 year old girl is going to high school. The 6 year old is going to primary school and the three year old doesn’t go to school yet. His wife sells beef meats and meat pies. And his job is to search out different communities where to purchase the livestock to sell and butcher on a weekly basis. His wife is his main support in the administration of the business. Aside from this source of income he also spends his time offering public transport with the help of his bus. He also sells grains, all of this to obtain the necessary income to cover the household expenses. One of his goals is to purchase another truck which will be able to expand his market, also taking the opportunity to provide his clients with transportation.

Felix is requesting his sixth loan, having been with Fundacion Leon 2000 for the past 12 years. Felix’s business is the buying, selling and butchering of beef cattle in the region of Telica. He is backed by 12 years’ experience in the business. He sees the need to have a source of income to support his family especially because every day his family keeps on growing. With time he managed to purchase a truck that helped him with his business. With this and the help of the organization he will be able to make his dreams a reality.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy T. is a 40-year-old married woman, and she has three children. She owns and operates a grocery shop in her neighborhood, where she sells items such as rice, sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, body and hair creams, and powdered milk.

She is now seeking a loan because she wants to increase her shop's inventory by purchasing additional bags of rice and sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, and boxes of body and hair creams. She hopes to increase her savings to support her children in school.

Mercy belongs to the community group known as the God is Good Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee each other's loans as social collateral (i.e., if one member does not promptly repay her portion of the loan, then the other members are responsible for curing the arrears), and they provide support for one another to repay their respective loans.

loans.use: To increase her grocery store's inventory by purchasing additional rice, sugar, vegetable oil, creams, etc.

loans.name: Ngveng

texts.en:
Ngveng T., 39, lives with her husband and four children in the Prey Veng province, Cambodia. Three of their children are students and one is too young to attend school. She typically makes $4 each day, selling various kinds of dessert. Her husband is a mechanic, fixing motorbikes and bicycles. On average, he makes $5 a day. 

Ngveng T. would like to take out a loan of $750 to purchase tools for her husband.

loans.use: To purchase tools.

loans.name: Patricio De Jesus

texts.es: Patricio de Jesús Sarniento R. quiere ampliar su casa  el cual ya tiene parte de la construcción pero le falta algunos detalles y quiere terminar para poder cambiarse a la nueva habitación. Lo quiere para comprar material y pagar mano de obra el cual solicita $6,000 pesos.
texts.en:
Patricio de Jesús S. R. would like to make home improvements. Part of his house is already built, so he needs to make the final touches to be able to move to his new room. He would like to buy construction material and hire workers to help him. He is requesting for $6,000 Mexican pesos ($450).

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Lopez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build a new room

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace K. is a widowed 60 year old trader and mother of eight children. All of her children are now adults. She resides in the Abofour community in the Ashanti region of Ghana. Her husband died after a short battle with an illness.

Grace is a very resourceful single mother whose hard effort brings income to the family. For the past three years, Grace has supported her kids through the sale of used clothing. Selling used clothing is big business in Ghana as brand new clothes are very expensive for the economically active poor. Grace travels to a nearby city called Kumasi to purchase her stock of goods. She wants to use the loan to buy more bales of used clothing to increase her inventory. She believes this loan will help her save for her children's future and rent a store to trade.

Grace belongs to a village bank called ‘Asedaben’ which means Thanksgiving.

loans.use: To buy bales of used clothing.

loans.name: Yan

texts.en: Mrs. Yan L. lives in Cheak village in Kandal province. She earns income breeding pigs, while her husband, Mr. Houl Lim, is a farmer who cultivates rice on a plot of land that he owns. The farming business is facing difficulties, because he does not have enough money to purchase fertilizers, pesticides, fuel, and hire laborers to work on the field. Therefore, Mrs. Yan L. has decided to take out a loan for these purposes.

loans.use: Purchase of fertilizers, pesticides, fuel, and hire of farm laborers

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Phượng  năm nay 36 tuổi . Chị đang sống cùng chồng và hai con đang tuổi đến trường tại xã Hưng Trung huyện Hưng Nguyên - Nghệ An. Năm 2002 chị Phượng tham gia Quỹ tìnhthương và vay vốn để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn.  Hiện tại chị Phượng vẫn đang sử dụng vốn để đầu tư cho chăn nuôi và nấu rượu bán tại nhà. Anh  Thanh chồng chị ngoài thời gian giúp đỡ vợ chăn nuôi còn đi làm thêm nghề thợ xây cho thu nhập 2.000.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 18.000.000đ để đầu tư mua thêm lợn và thức ăn phục vụ cho chăn nuôi
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyễn Thị Phượng, 36 years old, lives with her husband and two school-age children in Hưng Trung commune, Hưng Nguyên district, Nghệ An province. In 2002, Mrs. Phượng joined the TYM Fund and used a loan to invest in raising pigs. Currently, she is still using loans from the Fund to raise pigs, and in addition she now brews wine for sale at home. Her husband Thanh, besides helping Mrs. Phượng with the animals, also works as a construction worker, earning 2,000,000 VND (114 USD) per month. In the next round of lending, Mrs. Phượng hopes to borrow 18,000,000 VND (1025 USD) to buy more pigs and animal feed.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising pigs

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Married with three children, Paul makes his living by farming and selling household products.  This loan of $100 will be his first from GHAPE, one of Kiva's field partners, and will be used to purchase kerosene, oil, Maggi (a popular seasoning in Cameroon), plantain stems for planting and labor to assist in clearing his farmland.  

Because there is a constant demand for the household products Paul sells, as well as the convenient location of his store, he believes his business will succeed.  In addition, Paul is helping the community by purchasing the plantain stems from fellow neighbors.  

All three of his children are under the age of fifteen, so the profits of his business will go toward his children's school fees and to expand his farming business.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account, and most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Farm labor, plaintain stems, kerosene, oil and Maggi

loans.name: Godfrey's Group

texts.en:
G. Godfrey is the leader of Luwayo sub group in Lugazi. He has a retail shop business that has been able to expand as a result of injecting money from loans every now and then. He has five children that he has been able to pay school fees for, as he gets profits from his shop sales. He has also bought three cows out of his profits and hard work and these are now giving him milk for sale. Godfrey has also benefited from joining his lending group by being able to save and increase his savings time and again.

Godfrey needs another loan to be able to buy more shop products, so as to have more sales.

loans.use: To buy more more stock for his shop

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en:
S. Nguyen Thi is fifty-five years old and lives in the town of Hng Nguyen.  She is married and has four grown children.  To make a living, S. owns and operates a manufacturing business.  The main source of income for the business comes from selling food and daily use products in the local community.  S. has been engaged in this business for over ten years.

In 2002, S. joined the Kiva field partner, TYM Fund, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by giving her the ability to engage in business activities.  S. has successfully repaid previous loans from TYM Fund.  These loans were used to invest in expanding the business.  S. is now requesting a new loan that will be used to purchase machinery for the business.  It will be her eighth loan from TYM Fund.  S. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

loans.use: business.

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia C. owns a small sari-sari (store). She is 57 years old and has three children. She wants to make her business grow. Her wish is that her business will be sustainable. Alicia uses the income from her store to take care of her family's needs.

She would like to ask a loan of Php 7,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy additional stock for her sari-sari. "With my loan I could start expanding my business to a larger scale," she said.

CEVI helps small businesses grow. CEVI provides financial service to the poor. CEVI offers not just loans but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To buy additional stock for her sari-sari (store)

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther O. sells cooked food like rice, eba (a fried cassava dish), moi-moi (a steamed-beans cake) and drinks. She has been in this business for a long time. She is married with four children and she is 53 years old.

Esther hopes for the loan of N100,000 to purchase more foodstuffs and a deep-freezer to enable her to sell cold drinks. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and a deep-freezer

loans.name: Malai

texts.en:
Ms. Malai M., 27, is single and lives with her parents along National Road 1 about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh. She has one brother and three sisters.

Malai has been selling clothes for over two years. She buys them from a market located in Phnom Penh and resells them in front of a garment factory. She hopes to continue expanding her business so she can support her family more effectively. Thus, she is requesting a loan of $700 in order to use for this purpose.

loans.use: To continue expanding her selling clothes business.

loans.name: Christian

texts.en: Christian J. is 58 years old and married with 6 children. She sells sarongs and bags in the market. She hopes for the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more sarongs and bags to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs and bags to sell

loans.name: Ndika C Group

texts.en:
Maria is a member of the Ndiuka C borrower group,she is 45 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 5 children.Her children are aged 22,18,15,13 and 10 years.

Maria started her own grocery business selling soda,beer 4 years ago,she works 10 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 100,000 Tsh.

This is Maria`s first loan from BRAC.She requested the amount of 150,000 Tsh in order to buy more soda and beer.
With the profit she gain from the use of this loan Maria hopes to save more money and expand her business.
Estelina is another member of the same borrower group,she requested loan from BRAC 200,000 Tsh in order to expand her business

loans.use: To buy more soda,beer

loans.name: Rachel

texts.en:
Rachel M. is 23 years old, married, and has one child who is five years old. She lives in Kigali, the capital of Rwanda. For six years she has owned a small shop where she sells different kind of merchandise, as shown in the picture. Her shop is open everyday from 7:00AM to 6:00PM. Before starting the business Rachel was a full-time housewife and could not get enough money to meet the needs of her family.

With the new loan she has requested, Rachel will be able to purchase more merchandise for her shop which will help her to earn more profit and to expand her business. She also hopes that once this business grows, people in her community will be able to buy groceries. With the expansion of her business, she hopes to employ neighbors in the community so that they can send their children to school.

loans.use: To purchase more merchandise for her store

loans.name: Tulda

texts.en:
Tulda is a member of the Amani borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is 22 year old woman, she is married and a mother 2 children. Her children are 4 and 2 years old.

Tulda has owned a clothing business selling clothes for 4 years, she works 12 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 80,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Tulda`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 200,000Tsh in order to buy more used clothes for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Tulda hopes to save more money, pay school fess, get more food for family and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes for  sale

loans.name: Razia

texts.en:
Razia C. is a Tanzanian entrepreneur and business woman. She runs a tailoring mart sewing different types of clothes for both women and men. She also does school uniforms and other clothes for children.

The business area is at Kigamboni ward in Dar es Salaam. She purchases the business materials from both retail and wholesale shops at Kigamboni and Kariakoo city shopping center.

The business income helps her run her daily life and business capitalization. She needs a loan of TZS 600,000 to buy more business materials.

loans.use: To buy more business materials

loans.name: Frema

texts.en:
Frema is a very religious woman who always puts God first in whatever she does. Frema is 26 years old and resides in the village of San Vicente, Quirino, Isabela together with her husband and two children aged four years old and two months old. As a mother, she is hoping to provide the best future for her children. For that reason, she is striving hard to maintain her business and hopes that someday she could extend it to a more stable business.

Frema has been engaged in a hog raising business for two years. She needs additional capital to purchase more hogs to raise and their supply of feed and medicines.  For her second loan, she is requesting to avail herself of a loan of PHP 5,000 for the maintenance and growth of her hog raising business. She is hoping that her loan will be approved because it will contribute a lot to the progress of her business.

loans.use: To purchase hogs, feed and medicines for her livestock

loans.name: C8670 Tuzamurane Group

texts.en:
Y. Uwamahoro is 30 years old and married with three children aged 4 through 10. She and her family live in Rubavu District in Gisenyi Province, about 3 hours drive from Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.

Y. really knows her business very well - she has thirteen years of experience in the banana industry. She employs several people from her community and is known for quality products and good service. Her business yields a monthly profit of 50,000 RWF (approximately US$90) and she hopes this loan will help her to increase this amount.

Y. is requesting this loan from Vision Finance Company to provide needed working capital, to purchase inventory and to manage the cash flow of her seasonal business. She has had two previous loans from Vision Finance Company which she repaid on time and in full. Y. thanks VFC and Kiva for supporting her enterprise.

In the photo we do not see seven people because F. Mukarwego was not available.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Mrs. Thoeurn Pok Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan, which consists of twelve people, is located in Prey Kokir village in Takeo province. Mrs. Thoeurn P. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members.

Mrs. Thoeurn P. is a farmer who owns 0.7-hectare (1.75-acre) field on which she cultivates rice to earn a living. Aside from this plantation, she also raises pigs.

Since her pig business is doing well, Mrs. Thoeurn P. wants to expand it by purchasing more piglets and pig feed. She will use the rest of the loan to buy chickens to raise, too. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family’s standard of living.

Mrs. Thoeurn P. is the mother of three children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the others are studying in the local school. Her husband, Mr. Tuy Rom, is a construction worker.

loans.use: To buy more piglets, pig feed and chickens to raise

loans.name: Monina

texts.en:
Monina P. is from the village of Poblacion, Aurora. Zamboanga del Sur. She is 49 years old, is married, and has four adult children. Monina owns and operates a specialized retail store, buying and selling clothing products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over thirty-one years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. In 2007, Monina joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding her business. Monina is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her sixth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy is also known as Mama Linda in her community in Benin City in the State of Edo in Nigeria. She sells foodstuffs like rice, beans, onions, melons and cooking oil. She loves this business because of the profits. She is 38 years old and married with three children. Her husband is a police officer and he also supports their household. She is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift above poverty organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa.  She needs a loan amount of NGN 40,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Toilat

texts.en:
Toilat is 32 years old and lives with his wife and two sons in Bayan-Ulgii province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a traditional Mongolian housing tent called a "ger". Both his sons attend a local secondary school. 

Toilat has operated a taxi service in his town since 2005. He drives people around his town and throughout Bayan-Uulgii province. Before he started a taxi service, Toilat ran a grocery store with his wife.  With the income from the grocery store he bought a car. Now his wife runs the grocery store while he provides a taxi service for the residents of his province.  

Toilat is very hardworking and is known for his good character. He has gained a lot of experience over the years and is a trusted driver for his many customers. He works hard to maintain his success and is hopeful about the future. He is requesting a 200,000 tugrug loan to purchase new tires for his car.

loans.use: To purchase 4 tires

loans.name: Quiere Al Niño Group

texts.es:
“Quiere al Niño”, es una alcancía comunal conformada por  12 socios entusiastas y emprendedores, quienes realizan diversas actividades como: producción,  comercio y servicio, ellos vienen trabajando con EDAPROSPO- Prosperidad desde hace 4 años.
Dionisia Victoria asume el cargo de presidenta, tiene 50 años, conviviente, y tiene 5 hijos todos ellos independientes.
Desde hace 8 años se dedica al tejido a crochet (tejido manual), se inicio en este negocio porque inicialmente trabajó en una empresa, en el cual logró aprender y  decidió independizarse, actualmente trabaja con un cliente el cual exporta sus productos, además participa en un comedor popular de Horacio Zevallos y apoya a un sacerdote como asistenta social de ayuda comunitaria en diversas zonas del cono este de Lima.
Con el esfuerzo de su trabajo ha logrado la educación de sus hijos en una universidad y mejorar su calidad de vida.
El reciente préstamo será destinado a la compra de materiales para su negocio, todos nuestros socios agradecen el apoyo brindado y se comprometen a pagar en los plazos pactados.
texts.en:
“Quiere al Niño” is a community bank made up of 12 enthusiastic and enterprising members, who pursue different activities, including production, trade and services. They have worked with EDAPROSPO Prosperidad for four years. Dionisia Victoria, who is the president of the group, is 50 years old, lives with her partner and has five children, all of whom are independent. For 8 years, she has been crocheting textiles by hand. She started this business because she had worked in a factory, where she learned this skill, and decided to pursue it independently. At present, she works with a client, who exports her products. She is also involved in Horacio Zevallos’ popular restaurant, and she helps a priest as a social assistant and works to help members of the community in different areas in the eastern part of Lima. Because of her hard work, she has succeeded in sending her children to a university and in improving the quality of her life. This loan will be used to buy materials for her business. All of our members agree to help each other and commit to pay the loan installments.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy materials for her business

loans.name: Noemi

texts.es:
Noemí, de 35 años, vive en su casa propia al lado de su madre y sus 3 hijos: Zarai (9), David (6) y Jordi (5).
Desde hace un año, esta laboriosa mujer se dedica a la venta de diferentes productos comestibles en una pequeña tienda que implementó en su casa; para ello habilitó un espacio y en ese lugar atiende todos los días desde muy temprano.
Lo que más le agrada de esta actividad es que puede interactuar con sus vecinos y amigos y de esta manera no se le hace tan tedioso trabajar, además le genera buenas ganancias económicas que hasta el momento le han permitido sacar adelante a su familia.
Paralelamente se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza de una reconocida marca y gana muy bien por las ventas.
Para el futuro tiene planeado implementar una tienda más grande de comestibles donde tenga todo tipo de productos, una especie de minimarket donde pueda atender y administrar el negocio.

Este es el sexto préstamo que tiene con MFP y promete ser muy puntual en el pago de sus cuotas, como en las anteriores oportunidades lo ha hecho. Con el dinero que solicita comprará mercadería para su tienda y también productos de belleza para tenerlos almacenados y venderlos a un mayor precio.
texts.en:
Noemí, 36 years of age, lives in her own house in the company of her mother and three children: Zarai (9), David (6) and Jordi (5). For a year now, this hard-working woman sells an assortment of groceries in a small store setup in her house; she set aside an area where helps her customers every day since early in the morning. What she enjoys the most from this business is that she can interact with her neighbors and friends, and she does not feel the work is boring; additionally, it generates good profits that have allowed her get ahead in life with her family. In parallel, she sells beauty products from a well-known brand and the profits from her sales are very good. In the future, she plans to setup a bigger grocery store with a big assortment of products, like mini super market where she can help the customers and manage the business. This is her sixth loan with MFP and promises to make her payments on time, as she did with the other loans. With the loan she is requesting, she will buy merchandise for her store, and beauty products which she will keep in stock and will sell them at a higher price.

Translated from Spanish by Carlos Morales, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase merchandise for her store

loans.name: Sarin

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarin N. is a villager from Kouk Doung village, Takeo province. She is 40 years old and a widow with three children, one of whom is a monk and the two others are students in the local school.

Mrs. Sarin N. is a farmer who owns a piece of land to grow crops. Aside from a farmer she is a duck breeder who can earn a small income from selling eggs to support her family living.

Mrs. Sarin N. wants to take a loan of 2,000,000 KHR from AMK to buy more ducklings and duck food to enlarge her business.

loans.use: To buy more duckling and duck food

loans.name: Ronald

texts.en:
Ronald is a 26-year-old man. He has been running a unisex beauty salon and shop for four years. He has employed two people in his business. Since he joined Faulu Kenya he has been able to relate and socialize with his group members.  

Ronald hopes to grow his business to a wholesale shop and also hopes to supply cosmetic products countrywide.  He has requested a loan of Kes. 80,000 to buy hair accessories and add to his stock of beauty products. He describes himself as an aggressive man.

loans.use: Add to his stock of beauty products and personal care products

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Juliana Haine  T. is 35 and married with 2 children.  She owns a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  Juliana Haine  has 1 year of experience in this business.  Juliana Haine  needs a loan of WST $1000 to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 300 talas or US $125 per week) to improve/expand the business.  Juliana is joining the program to request a fund for developing her business for the sake of her family financially.

You can view pictures of a typical plantation in Samoa, taken by a Kiva Fellow, at:   http://picasaweb.google.com/agnes.p.chu/SamoanPlantation

In 2010, Juliana Haine  joined SPBD.    This is her 1st loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Juliana Haine 's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Juliana Haine  T. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.6 out of 3
Level of Education:                              2 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         2 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome

loans.name: Viviana Monserrate

texts.es:
En el Banco Comunal camino al progreso situado en la  ciudad de Montecristi en la Provincia de Manabí  conversamos con la socia Viviana, esta casada desde hace 12 años en cuyo matrimonio han procreado dos hijos, tiene 27 años de edad.

La señora Viviana lleva dos años con el negocio de venta de ropa y útiles escolares, en la casa tiene un espacio destinado con una vitrina para su negocio, ya es el cuarto  ciclo que lleva en la Fundación y ha podido hacer que sus ventas crezcan y sus ganancias sean mas altas.

Con este nuevo crédito nuestra socia Viviana invertirá en comprar más útiles escolares y ropa que tiene por  pedidos, en esta ocasión venderá más pantalones para damas y caballeros.
texts.en:
We are talking to Viviana, a member of the Camino al Progreso Communal Bank. The bank is located in the city of Montecristi in the Manabí province. Viviana is 27, has been married for 12 years, and has two children. Viviana has been selling clothes and school supplies for two years. She has a space in her house with a display case for her business. This is her fourth cycle with the Foundation. She has been able to make her sales grow and receive higher earnings. Viviana will use the new loan to buy more school supplies and clothes. She has received orders for these items. At this time she will sell more pants for women and men.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothes, pants for women and men

loans.name: Leocadia Valeria

texts.es:
Valeria tiene 56 años de edad, vive en casa propia con sus hijos. Ella se 
dedica a la venta en su bodega la cual inicio aproximadamente hace 12 años, con 
capital propio producto de ahorros. Valeria ya posee experiencia en el negocio con el 
cual apoya a los gastos de su casa. Ella posee una gran cantidad de clientes a los 
cuales los atiende de manera muy amable y calida, por esto y por sus buenos precios es 
que los clientes regresan a su negocio, el sueños de Valeria es incrementar su 
negocio, ya que esto hará que sus ingresos incrementen y así poder darle buena 
educación a sus hijos. Solicita el crédito para la compra de mercadería.
texts.en:
Valeria, 56, lives in her own home with her children. She has had a general store for about 12 years that she set up originally with her own savings. Valeria has a lot of experience in this line of work; it provides for her household’s expenses. She has quite a few regular customers that she cares for with kindness and warmth. Added to her fair prices, this keeps them coming back to her store. Valeria’s dream is to enlarge her business so that income will increase and she will be able to provide a good education for her children. She is asking for funds to buy stock merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise.

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda P. is from the village of Lumbayao, Tampilisan, Zamboanga Del Norte. She is 41 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. Imelda owns and operates a business growing and selling a variety of vegetables. Imelda has been involved in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month from it.

In 2009, Imelda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Imelda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC, which was used to to invest in expanding the business. Imelda is requesting a new loan, her 3rd, of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. Imelda plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Sofia

texts.en:
Sofia M. is from the village of Bolinsong Bonifacio. She is 38 years old and married with three school-aged children. Sofia has a store selling daily use products such as food for snack, candies, sugar, salt, shampoo, soap and toothpaste. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Sofia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from GDMPC. Sofia is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Sofia from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: 02.11.1.2 Nam Ngan Group

texts.en:
Nguyet V. T. (7) is a 52-year-old female living in the town of Thanh Hoa. She is the group leader of this four-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 02.11.1.2 Nam Ngan.

Nguyet is married and has four adult children. She owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling rice products in the local community. She has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 2,000,000 VND a month.

In 2009, Nguyet joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,626,900 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.

Nguyet is now requesting a new loan of 6,000,000 VND which will again be used to purchase additional products to sell. The loan will be her 2nd from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About the other borrowers in the group:

1. V. T. Hien (8) is a 47-year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her food stall.

2. D. T. Huong (9) is a 38-year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her general store.

3. P. T. Lan (10) is a 29-year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her clothing business.



About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:
The mission of Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


*****************************************************
Nguyet V. T. (7) là 52 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoa. Nguyet là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 4 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 02.11.1.2 Nam Ngan (02.11.1.2 Nam Ngan).

Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ buôn bán các sản phẩm từ gạo trong cộng đồng địa phương. Nguyet thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Nguyet kiếm được khoảng 2000000 VND. Vào 2009, Nguyet đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. Nguyet đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 1,626,900 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua các sản phẩm bổ sung để bán. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6,000,000 VND.

Khoản vay sẽ là 2nd khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:

1. V. T. Hien (8) là 47 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.

2. D. T. Huong (9) là 38 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hàng bách hóa.

3. P. T. Lan (10) là 29 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh quần áo.

Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:
Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Albertine

texts.fr: Née en 1972, S. Albertine est mariée et est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Albertine vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants au quartier Abokicodji à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Albertine habite ce quartier depuis douze ans environs. Le couple se partage les différentes charges familiales. Albertine n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Depuis douze ans, Albertine prépare et vend de l’«akassa » (aliment local fait à base d’amidon de maïs) à son domicile. Albertine s’approvisionne en maïs à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Albertine a déjà obtenu deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Face à la demande un peu plus élevé de sa clientèle, Albertine désire augmenter sa quantité d’approvisionnement et produire suffisamment d’akassa, ce qui lui permettra de couvrir toute la demande de sa clientèle et de se faire plus de revenu. C’est pour atteindre cet objectif que Albertine sollicite un troisième crédit.
texts.en:
Born in 1972, Albertine S. is married and the mother of three children, all in school. Albertine lives with her husband and children in the Abokicodji neighborhood of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She has lived in this neighborhood for about twelve years. The couple shares the different family responsibilities. Albertine did not go to school. For the last twelve years, she has been preparing and selling “akassa” (a local food made of cornstarch) at her home. Albertine buys corn in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She has already received two loans through ALIDé, loans which were paid back in full. Facing higher demand from her customers, Albertine would like to increase her supplies and produce enough akassa to meet all the customer demand and earn more income. This is her goal in requesting a third loan.

Translated from French by Rachel Braff, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy bags of corn

loans.name: Khursheed's Group

texts.en:
Khursheed is the wife of A. R. and they live in a city called Borewala in Pakistan. Borewala is famous for its shrines. Khursheed has given birth to three children: one daughter and two sons. Her daughter is married and her sons are still studying. The family lives in a small house.

Khursheed earns income by making bicycle seat covers to order. She is a very vigorous lady who always wanted to work to share the financial burden with her husband and to stand with him. She makes seat covers by using leather and soft foam to make the seat comfortable for sitting.

Khursheed is very happy to mention that, with her income, she has been able to marry her daughter. Her husband feels proud on her in this regard, too.

Khursheed’s husband operates a clothes-selling business and has been doing this work for over six years. Khursheed is applying for her second loan from Asasah to expand her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy more clothes to increase his sales.

In this photo, the two members, Naheed and Musarat, are showing the handmade fans that they make.

loans.use: To enable her husband to purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Jelnah

texts.en:
Mrs. Jelnah P. is from the barangay of Labuyo, Tangub City, Misamis Occidental. She is 30 years of age and married to Rafael, who is presently working in Saudi Arabia.  She is blessed with three children: two are now at their school age and the other one is an infant. To make a living, she is presently engaged in operating a sari-sari store and sells dried fish. She also is receiving support from her husband and earns income from renting their motorcycle for hire. She has engaged in these businesses for two years and earns approximately PHP5,000 a month from these business activities. 

In the year 2008, Jelnah joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jelnah as an active member of PMPC under the Regular Loan Program and has successfully repaid a loan amount of PHP7,000. She is now requesting a loan amount of 15,000 PHP as her fifth loan to be used for additional capital for her sari-sari store and dried fish vending activity. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family, especially in meeting their basic needs, savings for future use and her children’s education, loan repayments, insurance and possible business expansions. 

About PMPC:
 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her sari-sari store and dried fish vending business

loans.name: Ma. Amy

texts.en:
Ma. Amy B. is a woman with big dreams and the bravery to fight challenges in order to achieve her dreams. She is 40 years old and married to Roderick, 46, who is a fisherman. She is a caring mother to six children who are all minors. She lives in the town of Laua-an, Antique Province, in the Philippines.

She joined ASHI (Ahon SA Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, for the opportunity of having start-up capital for generating income. With her previous loan from ASHI, she carefully invested in her hog-raising business, and it gave her a reasonable income. Now on her second loan, she requests 10,000 PHP to continue raising hogs and to support her second venture—a fishing business. Specifically, the loan will be used to purchase additional piglets and feed, and the remaining money will be used to pay for a fishing boat for her fishing business. This loan will help expand her businesses.

As a mother, Ma. Amy dreams of sending her children to school and on to complete college degrees so they can find jobs for a better living. She hopes that her business will expand for them so they will have savings for future use. She also enjoys seeing that the loan from ASHI will change their lives and accommodate her family's needs. Through the support of Kiva partner ASHI, she will, step-by-step, realize her dreams.

loans.use: To purchase additional piglets and feed, and to pay for a fishing boat for her fishing business

loans.name: Belen

texts.en:
Mrs. Belen T. is from the Barangay of Baybay, Bonifacio, Misamis Occidental. She is 50, married to Sofriano T. and they have an adult child. To make a living, she has a sari-sari (variety) store and also receives regular support from her husband. She has been engaged in this kind of business for 30 years and earns approximately Php3,000.00 a month.

In 2010, Belen joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. As a newly recognized member of PMPC under the Regular Loan Program, Belen is requesting her first loan of Php5,000.00 to be used as additional capital for her store. She plans to use the revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of their family, savings, loan repayments, insurance, and possible business expansion. 
	
About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additiional capital for her sari-sari (variety) store

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more rocks to make crushed stone

loans.name: Octavio

texts.es: El señor Octavio O. P., tiene la edad de 52 años habita en el populoso barrio Laureles Sur, es casado y su esposa se dedica a la venta de nacatamales, comida nicaragüense que se oferta mayormente los fines de semana por su compleja preparación, ellos tienen 2 hijos adolecentes y uno mayor de edad que trabaja en la chanchera negocio de su papa, es para la reinversión a su negocio que el Señor O. solicita un préstamo para la compra de cerdos y destazarlos para su posterior venta y así mismo la utilización de la carne en las ventas de nacatamales del negocio de su esposa, ellos comenzaron a dedicarse en esta actividad, gracias a la enseñanzas de su padre, y es la actividad que representa el sustento diario de la familia y los proyectos a futuro para el bienestar de sus hijos, es por esto lo vital del préstamo para el continuo mejoramiento económico de todos los miembros de su familia.
texts.en: Mr. Octavio O. P. is 52 years old and lives in the bustling neighborhood of South Laureles. He is married and his wife sells nacatamales, a typical Nicaraguan food that she mostly offers on the weekends because they are complicated to prepare. They have two adolescent children and one older son who works in his parents' pig business. Mr. O. is requesting this loan in order to reinvest in his business, which is buying pigs and later butchering them to sell. They also use the meat in the nacatamales that his wife sells. They got their start in this business thanks to the teachings of his father. This business provides daily sustenance for their family and will provide for their children's well-being into the future, so this loan is vital to the entire family's continued economic progress.

loans.use: to buy pigs

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda M., from the city of Gango Ozamiz City, is 43 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Imelda owns and operates a service-based business providing sewing services in the local community. Engaged in her business for over three years, she earns approximately 10000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Imelda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 16000 PHP from GDMPC, she is now requesting her seventh loan for 16000 PHP to purchase materials needed to provide service. Imelda plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene K. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kalerwe, in the Kampala South region of Uganda.  She is single and has one child who currently is in school.  Irene has a retail shop, which she has had for five years.         

To help expand her business, Irene has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase soap and sugar.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Irene hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees.  In the future, Irene hopes to become an international business woman. Irene is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by giving her enough time to pay back her loan.

loans.use: To buy sugar and soap

loans.name: Inna

texts.en:
Inna is married and has 4 children. She runs a small business growing tomatoes, cucumbers and other vegetables in green houses. Inna has three green houses that provide enough space to grow the vegetables. The yearly profit is 40,000 Grivnas.

Inna is a hard working and disciplined person. She would like to develop her business further. She is requesting 10,000 Grivnas to fix the green houses and to purchase fertilizers. She needs to purchase new film to cover the green houses. She hopes to use future income to improve her family living conditions.

loans.use: To fix the green house and to purchase fertilizers.

loans.name: Olimkhon

texts.en:
Olimkhon K. is a 44 year old married man who lives with his 4 children and wife and owns a cattle breeding business. Olimkhon has 7 years of experience in this field. Since cattle raising and selling is a profitable business, Olimkhon has become a very successful businessman. Olimkhon has a friendly family who are always trying to help each other. He works very hard and spends his weekend time with the cattle, cleaning them, feeding and pasturing. Now, Olimkhon wants to expand his business and buy more cattle. So that Olimkhon applied for a loan of $3,000 USD. He promises to repay the loan without any violation and thanks all lenders for their support. 


More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History:

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing small cattle for developing business

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia P. is from Maquilao, Tangub City. She is 50 years old, married, and has 4 grown children. To make a living, Lydia owns & operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing hairdressing & beauty services to local community members. She has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Lydia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC, and is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase equipment to improve her business. This will be Lydia’s third loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family’s general living conditions.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisher-folk and small-business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase equipment to improve her business

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.en: Jacqueline is 24 years old, married and has two children who are between three and six years old. Currently, one of her children attends school.  Jacqueline owns a restaurant, which she has done for 5 years. Her husband is a precious metals dealer. Jacqueline will use the loan to purchase food and drinks for the betterment of her restaurant growth. With the new profits from her expanded business, Jacqueline plans to establish another restaurant. In the future, she would like a larger loan.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs and set up a new restaurant.

loans.name: Abdoulaye

texts.fr:
Monsieur Abdoulaye Koné est un homme marié de 27 ans, monogame qui est père de deux enfants. Il  vit avec son épouse à Flacoda, un hameau de Socourani, l’un des villages de la sous-préfecture de Fakola  dans une  famille traditionnelle élargie, Préfecture de Kolondièba  dans la troisième région (Sikasso) de la République du  Mali. 
Monsieur Koné, qui  n’a pas eu la chance de fréquenter l’école, s’est très vite intéressé aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment à l’achat ventes des produits agricoles.
Pour alléger sa pauvreté Monsieur Koné adhère au programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui  il est à son premier cycle.
Avec ce prêt, il compte acheter, 3 tonnes  de riz pour les revendre à Bamako et à Guèya, un village de la  République sœur de la  Côte-d’Ivoire. 
Quand Monsieur Koné vend son riz  à Guèya en Côte-d’Ivoire,  de retour il achète des ignames, des bananes, des pâtes de maniocs moins chers pour les revendre au Mali. Il s’approvisionne dans les villages environnants et espère réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de  100. 000  F CFA qui sera investi dans l’entreprise, les frais de santé, scolaire, nourriture et achat d’animaux.
texts.en:
Mr. Abdoulaye Koné is 27 years old, married (in a monogamous marriage) and the father of 2 children. He lives with his wife in a  traditional extended family in Flacoda, a hamlet near Socourani, one of the villages in the sub-prefecture of Fakola, prefecture of Kolondièba in the Third Region (Sikasso) of the Republic of Mali. 

Mr Koné, who did not have the opportunity to go to school, soon became interested in activities that produce revenue, in particular, buying and selling agricultural products. To ease his poverty, Mr. Koné belongs to the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso, and he is in his first cycle. With this loan, he plans to buy 3 tons of rice to re-sell in Bamako and in Guèya, a village in Mali's sister republic, Côte-d’Ivoire. When he goes to Guèya in Côte-d’Ivoire, on his way back he buys yams, bananas, and cassava paste cheaply, to re-sell in Mali. 

He obtains his supplies in the surrounding villages and hopes to make an average profit of 100,000 CFA francs which will be invested in his business, and also used for healthcare, school fees, food, and to buy animals.

loans.use: To buy rice

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael T. has six children, ranging from the ages of 13 to 25 years old. 

He has been working as a farmer for six years and produces goods such as coffee and bananas for sale. The main challenge he faces in running his business is fluctuations in weather, such as drought.

He has requested this loan of 60,000 KES in order to construct a bore-hole to drill for water, which may then be used to irrigate his farm. 

With the potential increase in income from this loan, he hopes to modernize his farming methods as well as improve his family's standard of living.

loans.use: To drill for irrigation water

loans.name: Najma's Group

texts.en:
Najma lives in a single-room brick house in the city of Lahore with her husband and 4 children. Lahore is the second largest city of Pakistan and famous for its history and culture. 
Najma is a 32 year-old house wife who spends most of her time at home taking care of her family. 
Her husband’s name is L. M., and he is a very hardworking person. He is involved in two types of work. In the morning, he does a government job on a monthly wage, and in the afternoon he sells iron to customers.  
Najma’s children are enrolled in a local school and are getting an education. It is a great level of satisfaction of her that she is able to provide education to her children. 
She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy iron in a larger quantity to fulfill customer needs and to increase his sales and profits. 
Najma is hopeful that her husband will be able to earn better profits by utilizing the loan and her family will be able to live a better standard of life. 
She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 6th loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit behavior and never missed any meeting.

loans.use: To buy iron for selling

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To use as capital

loans.name: Djawa

texts.en:
Djawa is 34 years old, married, and has four children between the ages of 9 and 17. All of her children are in school. Her husband is a motorcycle taxi driver. 

Djawa has been selling used clothing for twelve years, and recently her business has allowed her to buy a motorcycle for herself. She plans to use the profits gained from this loan to expand her business.

loans.use: buying additional inventory of used clothing

loans.name: Viviana

texts.es:
Viviana J. es una vendedora por excelencia, ella vende desde ropa hasta artículos para el hogar y bisutería.
Ella realiza su trabajo a domicilio, es decir  casa por casa va todos los días ofreciendo sus productos. Hoy ella quiere mejorar su pequeño negocio, y para eso necesita un préstamo de ₡500 000 (quinientos mil colones)   para la compra de mas productos que están siendo demandados en la comunidad, entre ellas ropa para mujer. Ella quiere crear un capital para poder construir su propia tienda y así mejorar sus ingresos
Viviana es  socia  de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal La amistad, una de las 110 Empresas socias de EDESA en Costa Rica.
texts.en:
Viviana J. is a saleswoman par excellence.  She sells everything from clothes to household goods and costume jewelry.  She sells her products door to door and goes out every day to do this.  Right now, she would like to improve her small business and, for this, she needs a loan for 500,000 colones so that she can buy more products which are in demand in her community, including women's clothes.

Viviana would like to build up capital so that she can build her own store and thereby improve her income.  She is a member of the La Amistad community credit company which is one of the 110 member companies of EDESA in Costa Rica.

loans.use: to buy women's clothes and accessories

loans.name: Dot

texts.en:
The woman shown in the picture above, Mrs. Dot N., is a 32-year-old farmer residing in the rural area of Kompong Tom province. She feeds some pigs in a pigpen behind her house. Eventually, she will sell her pigs to a slaughterer, and does so in four-month cycles. Besides this work, she has also been planting a rice crop, and that is her annual business. Her husband is a firewood seller as well as helping her in raising piglets. 

Mrs. Dot N. is looking for a loan to buy additional feed and piglets for feeding. She has three single children who are attending the local school.

loans.use: to buy additional feed and piglets for feeding.

loans.name: Encarnacion

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “SAN MARTIN DE ZURITE”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Zurite, perteneciente a la provincia de Anta y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Encarnacion; ella tiene 51 años de edad y es casada y tiene 9 hijos; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio de venta de verduras, ella vende tomates, cebollas, zanahorias, pepinos, lechugas entre otras verduras, la socia vende las verduras en el mercado de Zurite desde las 7:00 a.m hasta las 1:00 p.m, por medio de este negocio la socia saca adelante a sus hijos, la socia quiere ampliar el negocio de venta de verduras. La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar verduras al por mayor.

 La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Encarnación is a member of the "San Martin de Zurite" community bank which is located in Zurite district, in Anta province, in Cusco department.

Encarnación is 51 years old, married and has nine children.  She divides her time between her daily activities and her business selling vegetables.  She sells tomatoes, onions, carrots, cucumbers, lettuce and other vegetables.  She sells her products in Zurite market, from 7.00am to 1.00pm.  Through her business, she gets her children ahead in life.

Encarnación would like to expand her vegetable business.  She is requesting this loan to buy vegetables wholesale.  She is happy to be receiving this loan and pledges to make her repayments on time.

loans.use: to buy vegetables wholesale

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
Ibrahim is 35 years old and lives in the town of Ggaba in the Kampala central region of Uganda. He is married and has three children. All of his children are currently in school. Ibrahim has a poultry business, which he has run for five years.         
To help expand his business, Ibrahim has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more chickens for resale. With the help of his loan from BRAC, Ibrahim hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children.  In the future, he hopes to expand his business.

loans.use: to purchase more chickens for resale.

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Simon is a 59-year-old farmer from the village of Variani in the Gori district. He lives with wife Matiko and his mother. Simon's mother is 88 years old and retired. 

Simon and Matiko earn a living with agricultural activities. They have three milk cows, whose milk is used for cheese production. The cheese is sold to dairy product retailers. 

Also the family owns three hectares of land, where cabbage, tomato and wheat are grown. Harvested vegetables and corn are sold to local wholesalers. Simon has a mini-tractor which is used in his farm. The total average monthly income of the family, including Simon's mother's pension, amounts to 1000 Laris. 

With the credit received from Credo Simon will purchase fertilizer and fuel for the tractor. He will also pay the workers who will help him till and fertilize the land. Simon and Matiko hope that after fertilizing they will get a larger and better quality harvest, which will be sold to the wholesalers for a higher price. 

With the profits received this season Simon plans to purchase a better tractor for his farm. With this tractor he will also work in neighborhood farms and earn extra income. It will positively influence the income of the family. In the future Simon and Matiko plan to renovate their house.

loans.use: to purchase fuel and fertilizer, and to pay for farm labor

loans.name: Amaide

texts.es: Amaide  es una mujer casada de 32 años, que ofrece en su negocio los servicios de internet y comunicaciones, además de la venta de mercancías, aprovechando la clientela que diariamente la visita para acceder a sus servicios especialmente de soporte de tareas escolares a través de esta moderna herramienta. Ella vive en el municipio de San Juan Nepomuceno donde también está ubicado su negocio y como  le gusta el trabajo independiente, primero tuvo una tienda con la que  no continuó,  pues la vendió para comprar su propia casa e iniciar este último negocio, el cual quieren fortalecer y al que necesita  hacer adecuaciones para ponerlo a funcionar en un 100%. Esta es la razón por la cual  ha solicitado a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo su segundo financiamiento y a través de  su credikiva adecuará los pisos y comprará un computador para ampliar su cobertura de clientes, debido a que se está preparando  para la jornada de vacaciones escolares que se acerca y sus principales clientes que son los estudiantes, contribuyen a incrementar sus ventas, porque hay mayor utilización de su infraestructura técnica. Su sueño es terminar sus estudios de licenciatura en castellano y organizar su local independiente de su casa.
texts.en:
Amaide is a married, 32-year old woman who has a business offering Internet and communications services.  She also sells merchandise, taking advantage of the customers who visit her enterprise on a daily basis to use her services.  They use her business particularly to support school homework by means of this modern tool.

She lives in the San Juan Nepomuceno municipality, which is where her business is also located.  Since she likes to work independently, she first had a store that she did not continue with.  Instead, she sold it to buy her own house and start the current business, which she wants to strengthen and needs to make some improvements to in order to function at 100% capacity.

This is the reason why she has requested her second loan through the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo.  Through her kiva credit she will improve her floors and buy a computer to expand her customer base.  She is preparing for the upcoming school vacations and it is the students, her primary customers, who contribute toward increasing her sales because there is more use of her technical infrastructure.  Her dreams are to finish her degree in Spanish and organize her business locale separately from her house.

loans.use: improve the floors of her business and buy a computer.

loans.name: Saman

texts.en:
Saman is a 43 year old farmer.  Her husband is a worker and their combined income is $5 per day.  They have 2 children, 17 and 13 years old, and they both are working in weave factory right now with $5 per day for their income. 

Every month, she has to spend $20 on food, $6 on electricity, $15 on transportation, and $25 on other expenses.  She would like to request a loan of $1,200 to buy equipments for repairing her house.  She wants to prepare her house and then rent it to a weave merchant so she could earn some money from that.

loans.use: To repair the house

loans.name: Walter Rafael

texts.es:
El señor Walter Rafael  vive en la cuidad de Managua es una persona responsable es padre de familia.
El señor visito nuestra oficina para solicitar un crédito ya que necesita hacer unas mejoras en su vivienda el dinero lo va a invertir en la compra de zicn, perlines y el pago de mano de obra.
Don Walter  le agradece a ceprodel por que gracias a los prestamos obtenido anteriormente pudo mejoras su casa de habitación.
texts.en:
Walter Rafael lives in the city of Managua.  He is a responsible person and father.  He visited our office to request a loan as he needs to make some improvements to his home.  He will invest the money in buying sheets of corrugated metal and beams, and paying labor costs.

Walter is grateful to Ceprodel because, thanks to the loans he has already received from us, he has been able to make improvements to his home.

loans.use: to buy building supplies

loans.name: Bashiraan's Group

texts.en:
Bashiraan has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for improving her business of selling animals. She sells buffalo, cows, and goats. With the loan, she will purchase young animals and will sell them to butchers and to other people after raising them. 

She is very experienced and has been doing her business for the past 20 years. She is confident that an investment will bring positive changes to her business and she will be able to expand it successfully. 

Her husband is also an animal seller by profession. Both Bashiraan and her husband also get milk from their cattle to earn an additional income. 

Bashiraan has two sons: the eldest one is in college while youngest one is not yet reading. 

Bashiraan is confident that after the loan investment, her family business will grow further and her family will be able to enjoy better living facilities as a result. 

In the photo, the lady with a book (called an Asasah Passbook) is Bashiraan.

loans.use: To buy animals for resale

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah is a 25-year-old single lady living in a rented house in Kamwenge Uganda,with a dream of building her own house in the next five years. She has been a tailor for two years now and she is impressed with her customer's loyalty despite challenges in limited funds to buy the right quality of cloth materials. She has a passion to become an international fashion designer and she is determined to work towards her goal. Sarah needs the loan to buy cloth to sell.

loans.use: To buy cloth to sell

loans.name: Ngano Group

texts.en: Enock, who is in his late 40s, is married, and has five children who go to school, has been in the charcoal business for three years. He works from 7 am to 9 pm daily and makes a small monthly profit. This will be his third loan from Tujijenge, Tanzania. He used the previous loans to buy sacks of charcoal, to pay school fees and for household expenses; he has paid back all of his loans successfully. Enock wants a loan to buy more sacks of charcoal. His dream is to one day repair and renovate his house. He will share this loan with his loan group "Ngano", which has a total of 17 members who hold each other accountable for paying back their loans.

loans.use: to buy more sacks of charcoal.

loans.name: Salamat's Group

texts.en:
Salamat is the leader of this group. She is 74 and unfortunately a widow. She has raised two daughters, both of whom are married and live separately with their families. Salamat is engaged in cattle breeding and started this activity about 50 years ago. In the beginning she purchased a calf and then resold it at good price, thus starting to breed cattle. 

Salamat is a retiree. She receives a monthly pension in the amount of 3750 soms. She also cultivates agricultural products to make additional money for her livelihood. She applied for the loan because she needs financial funds to purchase a calf for breeding and a separator for processing milk. In the future Salamat wants to increase the number of cattle and soon she plans to start repairing a shed.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan.
